title: 109_s8
content: The "Child Custody Protection Act" may be cited as the short title. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new chapter on the transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits knowingly transporting a minor across state lines to obtain an abortion, in violation of parental involvement laws. Offenders may face fines or imprisonment. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits transporting a minor across state lines for an abortion without parental consent or judicial authorization, except in cases where the minor's life is endangered by a physical condition related to the pregnancy. Transporting a minor in violation of this law will not result in prosecution or lawsuits for the minor or her parents. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits transporting a minor across state lines for an abortion without parental consent or judicial authorization. It includes an affirmative defense for the defendant if they reasonably believed the necessary consent or notification had taken place. Parents can seek civil action for harm caused by violations of the Act. The "Child Custody Protection Act" defines parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision as requiring parental notification or consent before the procedure, with no alternative options. The term "parent" includes a parent, guardian, legal custodian, or a person standing in loco parentis with care and control of the minor. The "Child Custody Protection Act" defines parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision as requiring notification or consent from a designated person. The term "minor" refers to an individual not older than the maximum age specified in the law. The Act includes the District of Columbia and other territories in its definition of "State." Transportation of minors in circumvention of laws relating to abortion.
